author: Nicole Madigan
title: Kellie Finlayson: 'I'm 25 and have a terminal illness.'
text:
At 23, Kellie Finlayson's life was like most young women her age.
She finished university, celebrating the milestone with a European summer holiday, before returning home where she met and started dating Port Adelaide AFL star, Jeremy Finlayson.
It was around that time she began feeling some discomfort in her stomach. She didn't think much of it though. Back then everyone was intolerant of something, and Finlayson assumed she was in the same boat.
"It was popular for someone to say they had an intolerance to something, like gluten or lactose. It was almost like it was weird if you didn't have an intolerance," she tells Mamamia .
Watch: Deborah Hutton's message. Post continues below.
Video via Nine Network It bothered her enough to visit a naturopath, but the feeling wasn't going away, even with treatment.
"I was stabilising the symptoms , but it wasn't fixing them," she says. "So, I went to see a GP and did a stool sample which came back with some kind of discrepancy."
"Being a 23-year-old, they're not going to think it's anything serious," Finlayson says, and neither did she. By the time a new appointment was booked eight months later, she was pregnant, and wasn't able to proceed. Instead, she focused on her pregnancy, and the arrival of her baby daughter, Sophie.
Nicole Madigan Senior Writer December 29, 2023
Share via facebook
Share via twitter
Share via whatsapp
SMS Share via SMS
Share via e-mail 3 Comments Listen Now
00:00
How Matt Moran Really Feels About Fast Food What I Eat When 10 Things I Learnt In My 20s Fill My Cup ADVERTISEMENT After coming up for air from new motherhood, Finlayson found she was still experiencing similar symptoms as before, but now she attributed them to her new post-partum body.
"I thought everything was just from having a baby. I had nothing to compare it to. My partner joked about taking a Portaloo everywhere we went, because I always had the urge to go to the toilet."
But it was something else causing the pressure.
Kellie and Jeremy Finlayson. Image: Instagram/@kelliefinlayson_
ADVERTISEMENT The diagnosis. The ongoing bathroom issues prompted Finlayson to return to the GP.
"Then I found blood in my stool, and in three days I was finally having a colonoscopy," she says.
Finlayson recalls how kind everyone was to her when she came out of the appointment. They even let her partner and baby inside the clinic, despite COVID restrictions. She thought it was just a friendly place, but it was more than that. They knew what news she was about to be delivered. The doctor, however, was more direct.
"The doctor just turned a piece of paper around and said ‚Äòthis is what bowel cancer looks like'," says Finlayson.
"I was in a state of denial. Ended up leaving with my cannula still in my arm because I was so angry at the world. I didn't ask questions, and I didn‚Äôt understand what it meant at all."
Finlayson knew nothing about bowel cancer. She'd heard of breast cancer and knew it could be cured. She assumed a similar outcome for herself. "I didn't come to terms with the cancer being something that could kill you," she says. "The doctors were just so optimistic, my surgeon ‚Äî bless his soul ‚Äî would always say 'I'm quietly confident'."
ADVERTISEMENT Finlayson was diagnosed with Stage 4 Bowel Cancer. She was 25 years old, with a baby daughter, and a partner she hoped to marry. While she wasn't given a prognosis, Stage 4 is considered terminal.
"I think the mental and psychological toll of a terminal diagnosis is probably harder than the physical. My surgeon was cautious of making sure I was looking after my brain as well as my body."
Finlayson underwent a range of intense treatments that took a toll on her both physically and emotionally. When the treatment was over, she received unexpected and incredible news ‚Äî scans revealed no evidence of cancer.
"He wouldn't use the term remission or cancer free, but I was going well considering where I should have been at that point," says Finlayson. "I chose to be more positive rather than negative and I think that positive mindset pulled me through more than what I would have been able to overcome if I'd been set on numbers."
A crushing blow. As the end of 2022 drew near, Finlayson and her family of three returned to her hometown of Port Lincoln for Christmas. Within days, she felt breathless. Assuming she'd caught COVID ‚Äî it was everywhere and her symptoms matched what COVID-sufferers were reporting ‚Äî she made a quick visit to the local GP.
Being a local, the nurse at the local general practice had been following Finlayson on Instagram, and knew her medical history. She wasn't about to make assumptions.
ADVERTISEMENT "It was really lucky she was working because she sent me straight up for a CT scan," she says.
The doctor though, was unaware of her history, and explained the diagnosis of bowel cancer in explicit detail, as though she were hearing it for the first time.
"That was very hard to take, especially because I went there confident it was COVID. I had told my partner and mum I didn't need anyone to come with me ‚Äî I figured I can beat COVID if I can beat cancer."
It was a crushing blow. Finlayson was looking forward to spending a proper Christmas with baby Sophia, after spending the previous Christmas undergoing chemotherapy.
"I put it in the back of my mind, and was very much in denial again."
But on Boxing Day, she had no choice but to return to Adelaide, where the return of bowel cancer was confirmed.
Her oncologist gave her three options, depending on the outcome of an upcoming scan. If it was localised to one spot, they would do a resection and possibly some chemotherapy; if it had spread around the area to some lymph does, she'd have to do chemotherapy and radiation along with a resection; if it spread to other organs, that would mean palliative care.
Finlayson had her heart set on a resection, but the scan revealed the third possibility ‚Äî the cancer had spread. Her partner was optimistic about potential chemotherapy. She'd done it before, she could do it again, he said.
ADVERTISEMENT "But nobody knows the extent of treatment and how hard it is unless you've done it. Many people keep the pain to themselves, because you don't want your family to feel guilty.
"So, I had to explain to him, which was the hardest thing I've ever had to do. I also had to explain to him what that scan meant. My oncologist told me it meant palliative care.
"That day he saw himself as a single father for the first time. Even though we'd been through it for a year, he‚Äôd never had to wrap his head around me not being here."
While Finlayson did understand what the scan meant, at 26 years of age, she decided she wasn't going to palliative care, so she called her surgeon and said: find me a new oncologist.
"I did say I would never do chemo again because it was the worst time of my life. But once I found my new oncologist, I was soon hooked back up."
The couple were married in March. Image: Instagram/@kelliefinlayson_
ADVERTISEMENT Living for today. In March 2023, Finlayson married her partner, Jeremy, a milestone she'd never given up on.
After finishing the last round of chemotherapy in July, her scans showed the tumour was stable. That means the cancer is still there, but it's not active.
"It's not showing up in my blood markers at all. My body thinks there‚Äôs nothing there," she says.
It's now a matter of 'wait and see', including blood tests every three weeks, and scans every three months.
Finlayson's goal now, is to be healthy enough to be a good mum to her daughter, Sophia, and live a happy life for as long as possible.
"I'm not na√Øve, it's a terminal illness after all. I could live for 25 years, I could live for 50 years, or I could live for five months."
The Finlaysons are now ticking things of their 'living list', including a recent trip to Africa for their honeymoon.
ADVERTISEMENT "We have a lot of things on it. Our biggest one is to take Sophia to Disneyland for her 5th birthday. But that‚Äôs three years away. Another one would be when Jez retires, to travel Australia for a few months."
Kellie is now an ambassador for the Jodi Lee Foundation. Image: Supplied.
Raising awareness. Finlayson is now working with the Jodi Lee Foundation to help raise awareness of bowel cancer, especially for young people whose knowledge of this type of cancer is limited, despite it being the leading cancer killer for people aged between 25 and 35.
ADVERTISEMENT At that age, it's easy to blame bowel cancer symptoms on something else, which is why it's so often detected at a later stage.
"The earlier it is detected, the better off you are, the more likely you are to live," says Finlayson, who looks back on the initial colonoscopy delay and wonders how different her journey could have been.
Detected at Stage 1, bowel cancer patients have a 99 per cent chance of survival, at Stage 4, that drops to just 14 per cent.
Spotting symptoms can be tricky as they can be confused with common ailments, such as bloating, abdominal pain, unexplained weight loss, fatigue, unexplained change in bowel habits.
If you see blood in your stools or on the toilet paper, you should immediately visit the doctor. If you have symptoms you're unsure of, check out the JLF symptom checker , and visit your GP.
"You are genuinely saving your life just by going to see a doctor," she says.
To check your symptoms, visit https://www.trustyourgut.org.au/
Feature image: Instagram/@kelliefinlayson_
Do you have kids aged under 13 years? Take our survey now to go in the running to win a $50 gift voucher.
TAKE SURVEY ‚û§

author: NewsBreak
title: North Carolina Hit by Panera Bread Layoffs as Company Moves to Outsourced Baking - NewsBreak
text: Panera Bread has announced plans to close its fresh dough facility in Greensboro, North Carolina, on May 21, r esulting in 80 job losses. The company filed a Worker Adjustment and Retraining Notification (WARN) with the North Carolina Department of Commerce last week, fulfilling the legal requirement to provide at least 60 days' notice before implementing mass layoffs. The Greenville facility is one of several production centers that have traditionally supplied Panera cafes with freshly mixed and shaped bread dough, as well as pastries and other baked goods. These facilities have been central to Panera's food preparation process for years. The closure comes as part of Panera's strategic shift toward an "on-demand" baking model. Under this new approach, the company will outsource dough production to third-party bakeries using Panera's recipes to create par-baked and frozen products. These items will then be delivered to individual cafes, where staff can bake them throughout the day as needed. This operational change has already led to multiple bakery closures across the United States as the company moves away from its traditional centralized fresh dough production system. Are you concerned by this news? Do you think this will impact the quality of Panera's food? Please leave your thoughts in the comments section below and share this article with others so more people can join the discussion. To keep up with all the latest news in North Carolina and the United States, please click on the follow button!

organizations.name: the North Carolina Department of Commerce

author: RT en Espa√±ol
title: EXCLUSIVA: RT habla con Luis Arce tras el golpe fallido en Bolivia - RT
text:
Luis Arce en exclusiva para RT: "Siempre existen intereses externos detr√°s de los golpes de Estado" Publicado: 27 jun 2024 23:02 GMT Nuestra corresponsal Camila Lozano viaj√≥ a La Paz, donde tuvo la oportunidad de hablar en exclusiva con el presidente de Bolivia, Luis Arce, tras la tensa jornada que vivi√≥ el pa√≠s este mi√©rcoles con el fallido golpe de Estado. Adem√°s, no se pierdan la charla del mandatario con el expresidente ecuatoriano Rafael Correa en la edici√≥n especial del programa 'Conversando con Correa', solo en RT. Descargar video Luego del intento de golpe de Estado que se produjo este mi√©rcoles en Bolivia, el presidente de la naci√≥n, Luis Arce, ha concedido a RT una entrevista exclusiva este jueves en la que analiza y profundiza sobre el tema.
En di√°logo con nuestra corresponsal Camila Lozano, el mandatario coment√≥ la posible intromisi√≥n externa si se baraja la versi√≥n de que algunos actores en el extranjero estar√≠an implicados en la intentona golpista.
Seg√∫n precis√≥ Arce, en todo golpe de Estado en Latinoam√©rica, adem√°s de "intereses internos", siempre han existido "intereses externos". En el caso concreto de Bolivia, este fen√≥meno ha sido "pr√°cticamente una constante", asegur√≥.
Todos los golpes de Estado en el pa√≠s han tenido como premisa el tema econ√≥mico. El m√°s reciente de ellos, el del 2019, ha sido el tema del litio, coment√≥.
"Nosotros nos encontr√°bamos en ese momento negociando la adjudicaci√≥n de un contrato a largo plazo con el litio. Por eso nosotros nunca descartamos que haya intereses internos y externos siempre detr√°s de los golpes de Estado", asever√≥ el presidente.
En una rueda de prensa presidida en este jornada, Arce inform√≥ que al menos 14 personas resultaron heridas por los militares que participaron en la operaci√≥n golpista del d√≠a de ayer.
NO SE PIERDAN LA ENTREVISTA COMPLETA EXCLUSIVA DE RAFAEL CORREA CON LUIS ARCE EN LA EDICI√ìN ESPECIAL DEL PROGRAMA 'CONVERSANDO CON CORREA' .
Intentona golpista Numerosos militares bolivianos se apertrecharon este 26 de junio en la plaza Murillo, en La Paz, en las inmediaciones de las sedes del Poder Ejecutivo y Legislativo del pa√≠s. El presidente boliviano, Luis Arce, denunci√≥ "movilizaciones irregulares de algunas unidades del Ej√©rcito boliviano" las cuales, posteriormente, entrar√≠an por la fuerza al palacio presidencial. Arce afirm√≥ que se trataba de un intento de golpe de Estado e hizo un llamado a defender la democracia.
Personal militar realiza movimientos "inusuales" en la Plaza Murillo de La Paz, reportan medios bolivianos pic.twitter.com/FQUitXZta8
‚Äî Sepa M√°s (@Sepa_mass) June 26, 2024 Detr√°s de las acciones estaba el general reci√©n destituido, Juan Jos√© Z√∫√±iga, quien afirm√≥ que entre los militares hab√≠a "molestia" por el clima pol√≠tico en Bolivia y amenaz√≥ con la llegada de un "nuevo gabinete". Z√∫√±iga y Arce se reunieron en el palacio de Gobierno.
Aparece un video del tenso encuentro de Luis Arce con los militares golpistas en el Palacio Quemado, Bolivia. pic.twitter.com/U9kGIW1apg
‚Äî Sepa M√°s (@Sepa_mass) June 27, 2024 Posteriormente, Arce procedi√≥ a posesionar a un nuevo alto mando militar. Las tropas que hab√≠an llegado hasta la plaza Murillo se retiraron, una vez que los nuevos comandantes ordenaron su repliegue. Entretanto, Z√∫√±iga fue detenido horas m√°s tarde, acusado de encabezar la intentona golpista en contra de la Administraci√≥n del presidente. Al menos 16 militares y civiles tambi√©n fueron arrestados.
‚ùóÔ∏èEl Ministerio del Interior de Bolivia present√≥ ante los medios de comunicaci√≥n al general Juan Jos√© Z√∫√±iga, detenido tras el intento de golpe de Estado pic.twitter.com/Q4BZGRTQ3b
‚Äî Sepa M√°s (@Sepa_mass) June 27, 2024 En medio de los acontecimientos el pueblo boliviano sali√≥ a las calles en apoyo al presidente. Manifestantes se reunieron en la plaza Murillo en rechazo al levantamiento militar y exigieron prisi√≥n y todo el peso de la ley sobre Z√∫√±iga y los dem√°s involucrados. Con c√°nticos, expresaron su respaldo a Arce, tambi√©n conocido como 'Lucho'. " Lucho no est√° solo, carajo . Lucho no est√° solo, carajo", gritaron.
Ciudadanos se re√∫nen frente a la comisar√≠a exigiendo la prisi√≥n del general Juan Jos√© Z√∫√±iga por su participaci√≥n en el intento de golpe de Estado en Boliviaüáßüá¥ pic.twitter.com/vm2Ukt8pAo
‚Äî Sepa M√°s (@Sepa_mass) June 27, 2024 Muchos bolivianos permanecieron hasta horas de la noche en los alrededores del palacio presidencial como muestra de respaldo a Arce y su Gabinete.
Bolivia Camila Lozano Delgado Protestas america_latina comentarios You use your browser with disabled JavaScript. Please enable JavaScript for comments.

author: Amaris Encinas
title: Gypsy Rose Blanchard shares first selfie after release from prison
text: Gypsy Rose marks prison release by sharing 'first selfie of freedom' on social media [Amaris Encinas](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/5133245001/amaris-encinas/) [Gypsy Rose Blanchard](/story/news/nation/2023/12/27/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-case-timeline/72038395007/) commemorated her first full day of freedom with a selfie. She [ took to Instagram Friday](https://www.instagram.com/p/C1cNGBvu7IK/?utm_source=ig_embed&utm_campaign=loading) to mark her release from prison by snapping a quick pic of her smiling, writing ‚ÄúFirst selfie of freedom!‚Äù in the caption. Blanchard, who conspired with her then-boyfriend Nick Godejohn to [kill her abusive mother in 2015](/story/news/local/2017/05/10/gypsy-blanchard-everything-you-need-know-case/101499166/), was released from prison [early Thursday morning. ](/story/news/nation/2023/12/28/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-thursday/72047355007/) She pled [guilty to a second-degree murder charge](/story/news/crime/2016/07/05/gypsy-blanchard-pleads-guilty-murder/86617662/) on Tuesday, July 5, 2016 and served about 85% of her 10-year sentence, spending a total of eight years behind bars for her role in the murder. She became eligible for parole in September. Blanchard also [ recently announced the release of an eBook titled ‚ÄúRelease,‚Äù](/story/news/crime/2023/12/19/social-media-accounts-promote-gypsy-rose-blanchard-book-released/71966263007/) set to come out on Jan. 9. Here‚Äôs what we know about Gypsy Rose Blanchard. Gypsy Rose Blanchard coverage: [Gypsy Rose Blanchard's release from prison latest twist in shocking Munchausen by Proxy case](/story/news/nation/2023/12/27/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-case-timeline/72038395007/) Who is Gypsy Rose Blanchard? [Gypsy Rose Blanchard](/story/news/nation/2023/12/28/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-thursday/72047355007/), who is Clauddine ‚ÄúDee Dee‚Äù Blanchard‚Äôs daughter, was made to believe she suffered from a wide range of medical ailments including leukemia, asthma and muscular dystrophy thanks to her mother. Gypsy‚Äôs late mother was accused of having made her daughter appear to have a range of physical and developmental ailments, USA Today previously [reported. ](/story/news/nation/2023/12/28/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-thursday/72047355007/) Dee Dee Blanchard, later said to have [Munchausen syndrome by proxy](/story/news/crime/2016/07/06/munchausen-expert-says-gypsy-blanchard-case-unprecedented/86763054/) which is a mental condition in which someone makes another person ill for sympathy or gain received disability payments and gifts from charities all of Gypsy‚Äôs illnesses, that often led to painful treatment and procedures. Gypsy, who used a [wheelchair before it was discovered she could walk](/story/news/crime/2015/06/16/daughter-boyfriend-charged-murder-dee-dee-blancharde/28803189/), said she was desperate to escape her mother's abuse and sought help from her online boyfriend, Nicholas Godejohn. [Godejohn, who was was sentenced to life in prison](/story/news/crime/2019/02/22/nicholas-godejohn-sentenced-life-prison-blanchard-murder/2949249002/) for stabbing and killing Dee Dee Blanchard, traveled to Missouri on [ June 9, 2015](/story/news/local/ozarks/2015/06/15/greene-county-sheriffs-office-searching-mother-daughter/71236652/) to help enact the escape plan. He was reportedly let into the home after Gypsy‚Äôs late mother fell asleep and used a knife handed to him by Gypsy to stab the sleeping woman 17 times, killing her before fleeing to his native Wisconsin, USA Today previously reported. Gypsy later told [ABC 20/20 news](https://abcnews.go.com/US/young-wheelchair-bound-woman-treated-illnesses-ended-prison/story?id=52138979) she hid in the bathroom with hands over her ears during the act. Authorities were contacted about a post on Dee Dee Blanchard‚Äôs Facebook page dated June 14, 2015 that read, ‚ÄòThat B*** is dead!‚Äô before her body was [ found in her home](/story/news/local/ozarks/2015/06/15/greene-county-sheriffs-office-searching-mother-daughter/71236652/) with multiple stab wounds. Before Gypsy was publicly tied to the murder, many Springfield residents were worried that she was also in peril. The bizarre nature of the Springfield murder made national headlines and became the subject of [documentaries](/story/news/local/ozarks/2017/05/10/prior-premiere-hbo-film-gypsys-father-and-filmmaker-speak-bizarre-case/101438406/) and [streamed television series](/story/news/local/ozarks/2019/03/20/the-act-hulu-dee-dee-gypsy-rose-blanchard-true-crime/3228086002/). When was Gypsy Rose arrested? [Gypsy and her boyfriend were arrested](/story/news/nation/2023/12/27/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-case-timeline/72038395007/) on June 14, 2015 in Big Bend, Wisconsin. The pair posted two updates on Dee Dee Blanchard‚Äôs Facebook page earlier that day to draw attention to her yet undiscovered body. How old is Gypsy Rose Blanchard? Gypsy Rose Blanchard was born July 29, 1991, making her 32 years old in 2023. How old was Dee Dee Blanchard when she died? Dee Dee Blanchard was born May 3, 1967, making her 48 years old when she was killed in 2015. Who is Gypsy Rose married to? Gypsy married Ryan Scott Anderson in July 2022. Anderson is 37-year-old teacher based in Lake Charles, Louisiana, according to ‚Äú [People](https://www.msn.com/en-us/news/crime/gypsy-rose-blanchard-released-from-10-year-prison-sentence-early-after-mothers-murder-im-ready-exclusive/ar-AA1m9Bbi).‚Äù The pair split after three months of marriage but eventually reconciled, the magazine reported. She shared with various news outlets that she planned on attending a Kansas City Chiefs game with her husband after her release, stating that she hopes she gets to meet superstar Taylor Swift, who is dating Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce, USA Today previously [ reported. ](/story/news/nation/2023/12/28/gypsy-rose-blanchard-release-thursday/72047355007/)

author: Sergio Andr√©s Gamboa Mendivelso
title: Atenci√≥n| Nuevo atentado contra la estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a de Santander de Quilichao, Cauca: fue atacada con explosivos
text:
En la noche de este mi√©rcoles, 11 de junio, una fuerte explosi√≥n constern√≥ a la poblaci√≥n de Santander de Quilichao, en Cauca. Por segunda noche consecutiva, un atentado terrorista afect√≥ a una estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a en este territorio. Por ahora, no se tienen muchos detalles sobre esta explosi√≥n que habr√≠a sido planeada por grupos armados con presencia en el sector. Esta vez, el ataque habr√≠a sido con una granada y no habr√≠a dejado, hasta ahora, reporte de heridos por este hecho delictivo. (Adem√°s: Los videos que revelan que menor que dispar√≥ a Miguel Uribe Turbay no estaba solo: este fue su recorrido completo ) Otro atentado en Santander de Quilichao El hecho fue denunciado por la senadora Aida Quilcu√© del Movimiento Alternativo Ind√≠gena y Social, MAIS. En una publicaci√≥n en redes sociales asegur√≥ que "un nuevo hecho de violencia" se sumaba a la oleada de ataques registrados en el departamento del Cauca en los √∫ltimos d√≠as. En el texto, la congresista manifest√≥ que "se escuch√≥ una fuerte explosi√≥n en este municipio" que habr√≠a sido llevado a cabo con un explosivo que fue lanzado contra la Estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a. Comunicado Aida Quilc√©. Foto: @aida_quilcue
A la publicaci√≥n agreg√≥ un video en el que se ve las afectaciones que caus√≥ la fuerte explosi√≥n. En las calles junto a la estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a quedaron escombros y esquirlas de vidrio que salieron de las ventanas por el impacto. (Lea tambi√©n: Hombre es detenido por muerte de Angelina Resendiz, joven soldado desaparecida en una base naval en Estados Unidos ) Afortunadamente, seg√∫n las informaciones preliminares, no hay heridos por este hecho. El ataque marca la segunda noche consecutiva en la que la Polic√≠a es blanco de ofensivas terroristas. Por ahora, las fuerzas de seguridad buscan mitigar las acciones de este tipo perpetradas por las disidencias de "Iv√°n Mordisco". üÜò #ATENCI√ìN
Un nuevo hecho de violencia se registra en Santander de Quilichao, Cauca.
Hace pocos minutos se escuch√≥ una fuerte explosi√≥n en este municipio; seg√∫n versiones preliminares, un artefacto explosivo fue lanzado contra la Estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a. No se reportan heridos.‚Ä¶ pic.twitter.com/VSkJh2PyuY
‚Äî Aida Quilcu√© (@aida_quilcue) June 12, 2025 Segunda noche consecutiva con atentados El pasado martes, 10 de junio, como parte de la ofensiva terrorista en el departamento del Cauca, Santander de Quilichao fue v√≠ctima de un ataque con explosivos a la estaci√≥n de Polic√≠a. (Le podr√≠a interesar: El mensaje de Gustavo Petro tras muerte de Ana Mar√≠a Cuesta, directora del Centro de Memoria, Paz y Reconciliaci√≥n ) Seg√∫n los reportes, un artefacto fue lanzado contra esta edificaci√≥n causando una fuerte explosi√≥n. Sin embargo, antes de impactar la estaci√≥n, cay√≥ y no caus√≥ v√≠ctimas ni da√±os materiales. No siendo suficiente, los uniformados fueron atacados con r√°fagas de fus√≠l causando que las personas tuvieran que refugiarse en sus casas. Tropas de la Polic√≠a y el Ej√©rcito Nacional fueron desplegadas en Cauca y Valle del Cauca. Foto: JUAN PABLO RUEDA BUSTAMANTE
En este territorio hay presencia de las disidencias de "Iv√°n Mordisco" que ser√≠an responsables de los m√∫ltiples ataques en todo Cauca. En las √∫ltimas noches se han registrado ataques con drones y explosivos en municipios como Argelia, Su√°rez, Caloto, Villa Rica, El Pat√≠a, Corinto, Morales, Torib√≠o, Buenos Aires y Timbiqu√≠. El Valle del Cauca tambi√©n est√° siendo azotada por una escalada terrorista. que ha afectado a municipios como Cali, Buenaventura y Jamund√≠ y que han causado zozobra en la poblaci√≥n general. El Ej√©rcito y la Polic√≠a Nacional ya desplegaron tropas en los dos departamentos para intentar mitigar la acci√≥n terrorista en esos territorios. REDACCI√ìN √öLTIMAS NOTICIAS, Sigue toda la informaci√≥n de Colombia en Facebook y X , o en nuestra newsletter semanal .
topics: War, Conflict and Unrest->act of terror

author: jpost.com
title: Gaza deal is close, but not final, Arab official tells Sky News - The Jerusalem Post
text:
The draft agreement between Israel and Hamas to stop the war in the Gaza Strip is the best since the start of the negotiations, and ‚Äúits acceptance is imminent,‚Äù a high-ranking Arab official told Sky News Arabia.
The official anonymously expressed fears that ‚Äúboth parties can make a 180-degree turn and return to square one.‚Äù
He explained, "The private calculations of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and some Hamas leaders complicate the political decision to approve the long-awaited deal."
The official warned that "Netanyahu, for his political reasons, may reject the agreement even if the offer presented by Hamas meets Israeli conditions well."
Representatives from Hamas, Egypt, Qatar, and the United States met in Cairo on Saturday for talks on a possible hostage deal. At the same time, Israel delayed sending a delegation until the terror group gave a response to the latest proposal on the table. Relatives of Israelis held hostage in the Gaza Strip and supporters protest calling for their release outside Hakirya Base in Tel Aviv, April 25, 2024. (credit: TOMER NEUBERG/FLASH90)
Channel 12 reported that the US had given Hamas a guarantee that the deal would lead to the end of the war.
An Israeli diplomatic source emphasized that Israel was determined to continue the war, irrespective of any hostage deal.
Reports that ‚ÄúIsrael agreed to the end of the war as part of a hostage deal or that Israel would allow the mediators to provide guarantees for the end of the war are not true,‚Äù the source stated.
‚ÄúUp to this moment, Hamas has not given up its demand for an end to the war, thus thwarting the possibility of reaching an agreement,‚Äù the source said.
Tovah Lazaroff contributed to this report.

author: fijivillage
title: We need to resolve conflicts and promote harmony - Kiran
text: After losing two women due to the violence of their loved ones this year, we need to emphasise Jesus' calling this Christmas by being peacemakers, seeking to resolve conflicts and promote harmony. Assistant Minister for Women, Children and Social Protection Sashi Kiran says highlighted this during a Christmas celebration that was held at the Sacred Heart Cathedral Church, where the Shri Vivekanand Culture Centre and the Indian High Commissioner Shri Karthigeyan were also part of the event. Kiran says from this violence, 60 percent of our women have undergone some form of violence by their loved ones and 70 percent of all rapes reported this year were against children and minors. She asks how can we keep quiet when we know our loved ones are suffering, our elders and people living with disabilities get abused by their relatives who are supposed to provide love, support and protection. She adds these vulnerable are our people, they are our responsibilities and it is time to focus on the golden rule that is emphasised in the Bible by Matthew chapter 7 verse 12 which is Do unto others as you would have them do unto you. The Assistant Minister says the Golden Rule will also guide us in how we treat and respect other people, our environment as well our animals. Kiran says this is also an opportunity to inspire people of different faiths to live a more compassionate, loving and selfless life. She says if this becomes our way of life, imagine what a beautiful world we will all contribute to. Stay tuned for the latest news on our radio stations
